abstracts.cdata!:
The Telecommunication and Postal  Sector
            Reform Project for Mauritania had a highly successful
            outcome with likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development.  Performance by the Bank was
            satisfactory, while the Borrower's performance was
            highly satisfactory.  Lessons were learned in the areas of
            project design and implementation, telecommunications sector
            reform, postal sector reform, and regulation.  Lessons
            learned included: a) political commitment and ownership is
            essential for successful implementation of sector reform; b)
            the upfront definition of a vision or strategy for sector
            development is necessary; c) an inclusive and collaborative
            approach to project preparation and a precise time-table is
            paramount; d) communication campaign and media relations are
            essential; e) regulatory agency capacity development is
            achieved by technical assistance, training, and sustained
            interaction with the Bank's supervision team; f)
            indicators should be available and measurable and are
            essential for monitoring and assessment; g) the promotion of
            competition was a key factor; h) the adoption of sector
            legislation and the creation of a regulatory agency prior to
            competition and private sector participation are conducive
            to higher sector performance; i) privatization through
            capital increase and divestiture of shares can lead to
            success; j) postal sector reform is more difficult than
            telecommunications sector reform has less scope for
            performance improvement; k) capacity building activities
            should target both the regulator and the governmental policy
            unit; l) definition and enforcement of mechanisms to finance
            regulatory agencies activities is essential; m) beginning
            with a single sector mandate may increase the chance to
            become a performing multi-utility regulator ; n)
            institutional choices must draw on rigorous cost-benefit
            analysis; and o) monitoring and evaluation mechanisms should
            be included in the establishment of new institutions.
